00036 /// @file   util/Fs.h
00037 /// @brief  A class for working with the Os FileSystem.
00038 
00039 // We are going to use unix conventions internally
00040 // and translate them to the os requirements only when needed.
00041 // so we define these here.
00042 #define FS_PATHSEP "/"
00043 //#define FSPATH_INTERNAL_PATHSEP ":"
00044 #define FS_EXTSEP "."
00045 
00046 #define FS_UNC_SHORTLEN (200)
00047 
00048 /// Adds quotes to the path.
00049 #define FS_QUOTE_PATH(_path) std::string("'"+std::string(_path)+"'")
00050 
00051 /**
00052  * @class Fs
00053  * @brief An APT interface to the OS file handling utilities.
00054  * "Fs" is the simple 'paths as strings' library.
00055  *
00056  * APT should keep all paths in normalized (unix) format.
00057  * Fs.cpp keeps all paths as "/".  "\"s are converted to "/"s automaticly.
00058  *
00059  * This library converts the pathnames to windows as and when needed.
00060  * The programmer (you) should always use unix style paths.
00061  *
00062  * The paths are filesystem paths.
00063  * This is different than FsPath which is a richer represenation of
00064  * the location of a dataset.
00065  * (IE: No internal tablenames or groupnames.)
00066  *
00067  * All the methods are static to the class.
00068  * The only state is the class state of the error number and message.
00069  * (Just like the system errno.)
00070  *
00071  * The last param of the methods is the optional "abortOnErr"
00072  * which defaults to "true".
00073  * When "true" an error during the call
00074  * results in and APT_ERR_ABORT.
00075  * When "false" an error code is returned and the caller can
00076  * deal with it as they see fit.
00077  *
00078  * The "InPlace" functions are like the normal ones, but change the strings
00079  * Rather than returning a new string.
00080  *
00081  * Note: The convertToUncPath will not convert an already converted path.
00082  *       Thus calling it twice on a path should be safe.
00083  *       We want it to be this way as we dont know how many times
00084  *       this method will be called on a path.
00085 
00086  * Note: Many of the file libraries will call "convertToUncPath" for you.
00087  *       All you need to do is pass them a normalized path.
00088  *       file/TsvFile, File5 and the SQLite io code does do this;
00089  *       The legacy file IO does not.
00090  *
00091  * Note: All APIs are Windows 32KB path size compliant. This requires
00092  *       the internal use of std::wstring any time a file name is
00093  *       used. However the std::wstring implies more than just
00094  *       a path longer than MAX_PATH (260) bytes in lenght.
00095  *       The std::wstring also implies:
00096  *       1.) Unicode. APT code is NOT Unicode compliant.
00097  *           Therefore APT code should always use 
00098  *           std::string APIs, except when providing
00099  *           someone additional path, std::string API
00100  *           not provided here. Do not use std::wstring
00101  *           for application path names as this may
00102  *           allow Unicode characters to creep into paths
00103  *           that have ASCII encoding. File names in APT
00104  *           are encoded with application information
00105  *           and parsing of file names in APT is not done
00106  *           with Unicode parsing. Do not use std::wstring
00107  *           for file names and paths. 
00108  *       2.) Unviseral Naming Convention, or UNC.
00109  *           Unfortunately UNC is cognitive of Unicode.
00110  *           They do not refer to the same thing.
00111  *           Microsoft "Universal" means Microsoft
00112  *           specific. Specifially network paths
00113  *           must start with "\\?\" and be std::wstring
00114  *           for ALL paths, even those shorter than MAX_PATH. 
00115  *           All UNC paths then are also Unicode.
00116  *           For convienence Fs::Unc API will return
00117  *           the std::string UNC version so inspection
00118  *           of the full path being used. Given APT is
00119  *           is NOT Unicode compliant then the Fs::Unc
00120  *           returns std::string full path for ease of use.
00121  *       
00122  *             
00123  * 
00124  */
00125 
00126 // Maybe make this a namespace, not a class?
00127
